Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Quasi- Semi-Active Seats (QSAS) for Heavy Machinery
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project focused on a novel seat design that reduces vehicle-based whole-body vibration and shock will 1) better protect human health while 2) addressing major transportation markets including trucking, agriculture, construction, military vehicles, and mass transit, as well as automobiles and water-/land-based recreational vehicles. The envisioned socio-economic impact is significant: Continual exposure to whole-body vibration and shocks can cause discomfort, reduction in work performance, and chronic low-back pain for vehicle operators and passengers. Low-back pain is the largest component of disability among all occupational-related injuries. Though so-called "active" seats can help reduce these vibrations/shocks, their high cost is a major barrier. The low-cost seats being pursued here could benefit millions of vehicle operators. The work will also result in a greater scientific and technological understanding of the sources/effects of and potential remedies for whole-body vibration and shock. The suspension system market is projected to grow at a CAGR of 5.11%, by value, from 2016 to 2021. The market is expected to grow from USD 52.38 Billion in 2015 to USD 67.22 Billion by 2021. The market for bus seats alone is expected to be at $10.03 Billion by the year 2022.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on the feasibility of a quasi-semi-active seat (QSAS) technology. Seating design for heavy equipment and vehicle operators has faced a trade-off between performance and cost. The most-complex 'active seats' reduce vibration but are cost-prohibitive at $3,500. Semi-active seats are simplified active seats and perform better than passive seats, but still magnify input vibration and cost several thousand dollars. Passive seats are the least expensive, but they magnify input vibration at low frequencies. Recent design/material advances and strong preliminary data set the stage for developing an innovative passive seat at a fraction of the cost of semi-active seats that will reduce input vibration at low frequencies. Phase I feasibility will be shown using sliding friction to mitigate vibration at low frequency. A QSAS prototype will be built and used to show potential in laboratory and field settings. Technical challenges will involve material selection that will show maximum vibration mitigation and dissipation, as well as integration of the cushion with a suspension system that can handle the weight of a seated person. The research will determine effective performance parameters under different magnitudes and frequencies of vibration that simulate realistic operational conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. Studies show that heavy-machinery and truck operators are at high risk of suffering back pain and other musculoskeletal injuries due to steady exposure to whole-body vibration. In 2018 there were close to 5 million operators of heavy machinery, trucks and buses in the US alone. The estimated cost for back pain can exceed $2,000 per year, which can translate into tens of millions in healthcare costs to the heavy-machinery sector. Most existing seats in heavy machinery are passive and are not effective in reducing vibration transmitted to the operator in the low frequency range. The state-of-art seats with active and semi-active seats can provide more-effective vibration mitigation but are unaffordable for most users. Through our National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project, ActiBioMotion, LLC (ABM) demonstrated the feasibility of a novel family of quasi-semi-active seat  technologies that will significantly mitigate transmitted vibration in the low-frequency range, similar to semi-active seats but with a price similar to passive seats.  

Intellectual Merit. This SBIR Phase I project demonstrated the feasibility of developing a quasi-semi-active seat (QSAS) technology that has the lower-cost advantages of passive seats but does not magnify vibration at low frequencies, and outperforms commercially available semi-active seats in terms of functionality and price. Seating design for heavy equipment and vehicle operators has faced a trade-off between performance and cost. The most complex "active seats" minimize vibration at low frequencies but use computerized control methodologies and active energy-absorbing units that result in a cost of more than $3,500 to users. Semi-active seats are simplified versions of active seats and perform better than passive seats but still magnify input vibration and cost several thousand dollars. Passive seats are the least expensive, but they magnify input vibration at low frequencies. In collaboration with the University of Iowa, ABM has developed an innovative passive seat that reduces input vibration at the low frequencies, and is projected to cost a fraction of what comparable commercial, semi-active seats cost. ABM showed the feasibility of using a novel damping technique to mitigate vibration at low frequency.  Two functional QSAS prototypes were built and used to demonstrate the technical and commercial potential of the QSAS technology via laboratory testing.  

Broader/Commercial Impact.  The combined global agriculture, construction, mining, heavy-duty truck, and bus seat market is expected to be valued at $10.85 Billion by 2025, at a Combined Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 5.5%. One key driver for this growth is the need to have next-generation premium seat technology available to address healthcare costs/concerns and the need to retain experienced operators of heavy machinery and vehicles, specifically as it relates to back pain and injuries. ABM's future efforts, when successful, will have the potential to help reduce risk and severity of musculoskeletal injuries among operators of heavy machinery and vehicles incorporating ABM's seat technologies. This, in turn, would provide significant health and financial benefits to workers, their employers, and other stakeholders in safety and injury prevention, and would lower workers compensation insurance costs. ABM's novel seat designs and approaches can also enrich mechanical and structural engineering disciplines at colleges and provide great opportunities for students to learn new concepts, expand their research curiosity and innovation, and possibly discover new materials and mechanical processes. ABM's new approach to designing seats and their suspension systems could inspire students in STEM disciplines. The ABM team projects that they and their partners will have a solid foothold in the heavy-machinery and vehicle market by 2024.
